FeCx@C catalysts prepared from Prussian blue and their applications in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis Bingshuang Li Data curation Formal analysis Writing – original draft a b Guangbo Liu Supervision Methodology Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Shengnan Yang Formal analysis Conceptualization a b Hui Wang Data curation Formal analysis a Jianqing Li Formal analysis a Jinhu Wu Supervision Conceptualization Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences Qingdao 266101 China Key Laboratory of Biofuels, Qingdao Institute of Bioenergy and Bioprocess Technology, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Qingdao 266101, China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The activity and selectivity of the Fe-based catalysts with different FeCx species had been long debated in Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). In this manuscript, FeCx was encapsulated in carbon matrix by Prussian blue (Fe4(Fe(CN)6)3, PB) thermal treated, and the FeCx@C catalysts could be directly prepared. With the calcination temperature increasing, the FeCx species of core and the thickness of carbon shell in FeCx@C catalysts can be continuously tuned through adjusting the calcination temperature. Further characterization results suggested that the decarburization of FeCx@C catalyst occurred from the inside to the outside. In addition, the FTS results showed the value of carbon-chain growth probability (α value) presented the positive relationship with the catalyst calcination temperature. This work provides a novel and simple route to synthesize FeCx@C catalyst, and also provides evidence for the mechanism of FeCx species from the perspective of decarburization. Graphical Abstract Schematic of the FeCx@C catalysts prepared from PB at different calcination temperatures and their FTS performance of catalysts. ga1 Keywords Prussian blue Fischer-Tropsch synthesis FeCx@C core-shell catalyst Iron carbide species Thickness of the carbon shell 1 Introduction Dramatic energy demand, depletion of fossil resources, and global warming are the major problems being faced humankind in the modern society. Syngas (H2/CO), an important platform for conversion and utilization of carbon-containing resources, can be produced from biomass, waste, carbon dioxide, coal, etc [1–5]. Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS), which is a promising route to transform syngas into fuels and important chemicals, is considered as a key route for resolving environmental and energy problems [6–8]. Iron-based (Fe-based) catalyst is widely used in FTS industrial, due to its low cost, wide adaptability of H2/CO rates, and flexible operating conditions [9,10]. Fe-based catalysts with core-shell structures have been accepted as a kind of excellent catalysts in FTS, because certain structure can limit the sintering of Fe active sites and adjust product selectivity in the reaction. Traditionally, the core-shell catalysts have been synthesized by many steps following by the Fe active sites formation [11,12]. However, in these processes, the interface interaction between the core and shell affected the catalytic performances. Recently, the FTS catalyst prepared from metal-organic materials had been studied widely and exhibited preferential performance. The carbide species, can be directly prepared from metal-organic materials, and present special catalyst structure and some even could be transformed into core-shell structure by simple treatment. Gascon et al. used Fe-BTC as precursor to prepare FeCx@C catalysts, and the ε-Fe2.2C and χ-Fe5C2 catalysts can be selectively obtained by controlling the calcination temperature, and these catalysts exhibited high catalytic activity in FTS [13–16]. Lyu et al. succeed in stabilizing pure-phase ε-Fe2C nanocrystals by confining FeCx species into graphene shells through mixture of iron salt and organic species (Fe(NO3)3, urea, glucose, etc) calcined, and the obtained catalyst exhibited excellent activity and stability [17]. Generally, the catalysts obtained from metal-organic materials promoted the catalyst activity and stability in the FTS, but the complicated preparation methods, precise structure control conditions and high costs limited the application of these catalysts in industrial production. Prussian blue (Fe4(Fe (CN)6)3, PB), as a kind of usual metal-organic material with a clear structure, can be obtained easily and cheaply. Similar to other metal-organic materials, PB calcined under the inert atmosphere is also an organic compound decomposition and volatilization process, and easily forms one or many FeCx@C species simultaneously [18–25]. In this process, the carbon content in the catalyst could be adjusted by altering the calcination temperature. In addition, with the carbon content varying, the two kinds of iron phase may provide more complicated phases of iron carbides, and the thickness of the shell for the core-shell catalyst can also be continuously tuned. Although some studies about thermal behavior of PB had been reported, most of catalysts prepared from PB thermal decomposition did not exhibit good FTS performance [26–28]. Furthermore, there were few works reported to prepare and evaluate FeCx@C catalysts with continuous adjusted structure in the FTS. In this manuscript, the core-shell FeCx@C catalysts with continuous adjustment structure are prepared from PB calcined under inert atmosphere, and the physicochemical properties of the catalysts are also characterized. These catalysts are evaluated over a flow fixed-bed reactor, and the variation of the catalytic activity with the structural change is investigated. The relationship between the structure and performance of the catalysts is also discussed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of PB precursor The PB precursors were prepared using a co-precipitation method. A 0.4 M ferric nitrate solution (≥98.5%, analytical grade purity, Shanghai Chemical Reagents Co. Ltd, China.) and 0.3 M sodium ferrocyanide (≥99%, analytical grade purity, Shanghai Chemical Reagents Co. Ltd, China) were added into a beaker and stirred at room temperature. Then the obtained mixture was stirred and aged at room temperature for 24 h. The precipitate was washed three times with deionized water. And then, it was dried at 60 °C for 12 h. The as-synthesized PB was used for calcination and future characterization. 2.1.2 Catalysts preparation The as-synthesized PB was calcined in a furnace under a controlled flow of Ar. The precursor was slowly heated to 200 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C/min and kept at 200 °C for 3 h in the furnace. The sample was then heated to 450 °C for 4 h with 2 °C/min rate, and the obtained catalyst was assigned as PB-C-450. The other catalysts were prepared following as the same front steps, but were calcined at different temperatures. These catalysts were named as the last calcination temperatures, like PB-C-470, PB-C-500, PB-C-530, PB-C-560 and PB-C-600. 2.2 Catalysts characterization Thermo gravimetric analysis (TGA) was conducted using a STA449F5 Jupiter thermogravimetric analyzer. The temperature was linearly increased from room temperature to 700 °C with a heating rate of 2 °C/min under Ar flow. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was acquired using a Bruker Equinox 55 spectrometer equipped with a DLaTGS detector and operated at room temperature and atmospheric pressure. Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses of the catalysts were performed by Bruker D8 Advance X with Cu Kα (λ = 1.5418 Å) in the scan range of 5–80 ° with a scanning step of 2 °/min. The crystal phase was determined by comparing with the standard PDF card. The Raman analyses (Raman) were carried out on Raman Thermo Scientific DXR Raman Microscope with laser excitation wavelength of 532 nm at room temperature. N2 physical adsorption and desorption experiments were carried out on Micromeritics Tristar 3000 sorptometer to detect the specific surface area and pore structure of the catalyst. Before analysis, the sample was heated to 200 °C at 10 °C/min and degassed for 6 h. The catalyst surface was determined by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method, and the micropore volume was measured by t-plot method. The elements contents were measured using the IRIS/AP full-spectrum direct-reading inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES) produced by ARL Company. The high frequency power, 1150 W, the auxiliary gas flow rate, 0.5 L/min, the peristaltic pump speed, 100 rpm, the integration time, 15 s, the carrier gas pressure, 221.05 × 103 Pa, and the injection volume, 1.85 cm3/min. The morphologies of the catalysts were characterized by High Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM). HRTEM images were obtained by using a FEI Technai G2 F20 microscope operating at the accelerating voltage of 200 kV. Before analysis, the sample was ultrasonically dispersed in ethanol solution for 5 min, and a drop of solution was deposited on the carbon film supported 300 mesh copper grid. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out using a Thermo ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer with Mg Kα X-ray excitation source (hv=1235.6 eV). The binding energy of C1s (284.6 eV) was used as the reference to correct the binding energy of the catalysts. The H2-TPR results were performed on a Micromeritics Chemisorption Analyzer 2920TR equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample (100 mg) was pretreated with Ar at 400 °C for 2 h and then cooled to 100 °C. After that, a 10% H2/Ar mixture gas was switched on and the temperature was increased linearly at a rate of 2 °C/min from 100 to 700 °C. The in-situ DRIFTS experiments were carried out on the FTIR spectrometer (Hitachi Tracer 100 combined with mercury-cadmium telluride detector) with in-situ diffuse reflection cell. The in-situ DRIFTS study was performed using syngas with the composition of 45%CO, 45%H2 and 10% N2. The in-situ cell was purified by Ar before the reaction. After background testing, the catalysts were heated to be pretreated and employed in the reaction. The catalysts were pre-treated at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled. During the experiment, the absorption spectra were collected at syngas atmosphere on 290 °C. The room temperature 57Fe Mössbauer spectra (MES) of the different catalysts were recorded on a Topologic 500 A spectrometer equipped with a proportional counter. Magnetic hyperfine field was calibrated with the 330 kOe field of α-Fe at ambient temperature. The identification of different FeCx species was based on the fitting parameters, including isomer shift (IS), quadrupole splitting (QS) and hyperfine magnetic field (H). The relative content of FeCx species was calculated by integrating the area of each phase. The CO temperature-programmed desorption (CO-TPD) results were performed on a Micromeritics Chemisorption Analyzer 2920TR equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). The sample (100 mg) was pretreated in Ar at 400 °C for 2 h and then cooled down to 50 °C. After that, 10% CO/Ar mixture was introduced to adsorption at 50 °C for 30 min, and then the samples were purged for 30 min. After that, the temperature was increased linearly at a rate of 2 °C/min from 50 to 500 °C, and the CO was detected by the TCD. 2.3 FTS evaluation The FTS reactions were carried out in a continuous flow type fixed-bed reactor with an inner diameter of 10 mm containing catalyst (1 g, 40–60mesh) diluted with ground quartz (Vcatalyst: Vquartz=1:1). The catalyst was treated in a Ar flow (25 ml/min) for 2 h before reaction. The reactant mixture containing 45% CO, 45% H2 and 10% N2 was measured using a mass flow controller, and the flow rate of the outlet gas was measured using a wet-gas flowmeter. The tail gas was detected online using an Agilent 7890 A equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a flame ionization detector. Products in the cold and hot trap were collected every 24 h and analyzed offline by Agilent 7820 A fitted with DB-1 column and a flame ionization detector. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Thermal behavior of PB Fig. 1 showed the TG behavior of PB sample under argon atmosphere up to 700 °C. As shown in Fig. 1, with the increasing of temperature, there were 4 wt loss stages for the PB decomposition. The first weight loss (below 200 °C) with a mass loss of up to 28% was assigned to adsorbents and crystal water desorbed from the PB structure. The second stage (200–400 °C) corresponded to decomposition of the cyanide group (CN) and the release of free gaseous nitrogen [13]. In the third stage (400–650 °C), the FeCx species were generated and the sample weight decreased with the change of FeCx phase with the formation of solid free carbon. In the fourth stage (exceeding 650 °C), the weight loss almost stopped, and the stable FeCx was formed [25,26]. These results showed that the FTS catalysts could be obtained at 450–600 °C. The FT-IR spectra were used to confirm the PB decomposition degrees in the catalysts from different temperatures, especial the CN bond in PB. As shown in Fig. 2, the PB sample presented two peaks in 450–4000 cm−1 region. The absorption peak at 494 cm−1 was attributed to [CN-FeIII], while the peak at 2100 cm−1 was assigned to [FeII-CN-FeIII] [29]. However, these two peaks disappeared in all the catalysts after thermal treatment at different temperatures, and there no other new peaks formed. It suggested that the [CN-FeIII] bonds of the catalysts were cracked above 450 °C, and the same results can also be obtained from the TG curve. 3.2 Characterizations of catalysts calcined from different temperature The XRD patterns of the catalysts prepared from different temperatures were shown in Fig. 3. The catalysts showed the obvious FeCx diffraction peaks, and different FeCx species were identified by comparison with the standard data in the literature. For the PB-C-450 catalyst, the pattern can be assigned to orthorhombic ε-Fe2C as main structure (PDF#36-1249). It was reported that the ε-Fe2C phase was easy to be decomposed above 300 °C, due to the high carbon content and the higher space group symmetry than other iron carbides [12,30]. However, attributed to the core-shell structure and the carbon rich original, the ε-Fe2C was found to exist stably at the high temperature in this work. The PB-C-470 catalyst exhibited the same diffraction peaks of orthorhombic ε-Fe2C as PB-C-450, and also presented some new peaks at 42.8°, 43.6° and 44.6°, which can be attributed to χ-Fe5C2 (PDF#36-1248) and Fe (PDF#06-0696). It can be easily understood that with the increase of calcination temperature, the catalysts became more carbon-lean, and the ε-Fe2C decarburized to χ-Fe5C2 and α-Fe. For the PB-C-500 catalyst, the peaks assigned to ε-Fe2C had disappeared, and the χ-Fe5C2 and θ-Fe became the main existing forms in the catalyst. The PB-C-530 catalyst exhibited the similar X-ray diffraction results with the PB-C-500 at 42.8° and 45.9°; moreover, the intensity of the χ-Fe5C2 peaks decreased, while the peaks intensity of Fe increased. In addition, the peak of PB-C-530 catalyst at 43.6° moved to 43.8°, and that suggested a new phase formed which can be attributed to the θ-Fe3C (PDF#03-0411) [12]. For the PB-C-560 and PB-C-600, these two catalysts presented the same X-ray diffraction results, and there may also exist two phases containing θ-Fe3C and α-Fe. The XRD results suggested that with increasing calcination temperature, the FeCx structure in the catalysts presented the evolutional rule as follows: ε-Fe2C → χ-Fe5C2 →θ-Fe3C →α-Fe. The XRD patterns were also used to characterize the existing forms of carbon in the catalysts. The diffraction peak of the graphitic carbon always presents at 2θ around 26.1°, in this works, no peaks appeared at 26.1°, which may be attributed to the low carbon contents and small particles. MES was also employed to analysis the phase composition of FeCx species, and the results were shown in Fig. 4 and Table 1. For PB-C-450, PB-C-470, PB-C-500, PB-C-530 and PB-C-560 catalysts, there presented four sets of sextet spectra and one set of one paramagnetic doublet. For PB-C-600, only two sets of sextet spectra could be observed. The different FeCx species were identified by comparison with the literatures [31–34]. As shown in Table 1, it can be seen that the ε-Fe2C and χ-Fe5C2 was the main phases, and ε-Fe2C (65.2%) held the absolute majority in the PB-C-450 catalyst. PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts presented the same FeCx phases with the PB-C-450, but χ-Fe5C2 became the most component. In the PB-C-530, the θ-Fe3C phase appeared and ε-Fe2C disappeared. For the PB-C-560, the θ-Fe3C took the most positions of the FeCx, and the χ-Fe5C2 occupied only 11.6%. In the PB-C-600, the FeCx was composed of α-Fe and θ-Fe3C. These results indicated the FeCx phase attribution and the evolutional rule of the catalysts were the same as the XRD results. The Raman spectra were employed to investigate the existing form of the carbon in the different catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5, all catalysts displayed D bands at 1344 cm−1, G bands at 1585 cm−1 and 2D bands at 2688 cm−1 [18]. This indicated that the carbon atoms in the catalysts existed as a mixture of amorphous and graphitic carbon and presented the similar existing forms. Generally, the relative integrated intensity of these two bands (ID/IG, which was calculated according to intensity of corresponding peak) can be used to reflect the disorder degree of carbon atoms [31,32]. In Fig. 5, for all the catalysts, with the increase of calcination temperature, the intensity of D band (ID) and G band (IG) vibration peaks were decreased, and the ID/IG ratios were also decreased. It suggested that the carbon loss and the enhancement of graphitization degree appeared in the catalysts with an increase in calcination temperature. Fig. 6 showed the HRTEM images and particle size distribution of the catalysts prepared from different temperatures. As shown in Fig. 6, all the catalyst particles showed the almost same sizes, and the average sizes of particles were all in 80–120 nm (Fig. 6a-1, a-4; b-1, b-4; c-1, c-4; d-1, d-4; 6e-1, e-4, and f-1, f-4). In addition, all the catalysts presented the carbon encapsulated core-shell structure, and the core-shell particles were composed of iron or iron carbides core covered with carbon layers. However, for the PB-C-450 and PB-C-470 catalysts, there presented an initial state of the core-shell structure, and the core-shell structure was not clear in the HRTEM image (Fig. 6a-1, a-2, b-1, b-2), this may due to the graphite structure was not easy to form at a lower calcination temperature (Fig. 6a-3, b-3). For the other catalysts, there presented clear core-shell structure and the thicknesses of the carbon shell in catalysts were decreased with the calcination temperature increasing (Fig. 6c-2, d-2, e-2, and f-2). Moreover, the lattice fringes in the core and the shell were measured to reveal the structure of the catalysts. For the PB-C-450, there was only one kind of lattice fringe and the lattice spacing was 0.210 nm which was assigned to the (101) plane of ε-Fe2C in the core structure [35]. For the shell, two carbon forms existed in the PB-C-450 catalyst, and the amorphous carbon was the main existing form. This can be inferred in the Raman results. For the PB-C-470 catalyst, it can be seen different lattice fringes in the core structure. Similar to PB-C-450, the lattice spacing was 0.210 nm that can be assigned to the (101) plane of ε-Fe2C, and the lattice spacing can be attributed to (021) plane of χ-Fe5C2 about 0.208 nm. This was consistent with the XRD results. Then the amorphous carbon coated on FeCx (ε-Fe2C+ χ-Fe5C2 + α-Fe) acts as shell. For the PB-C-500 catalyst, two kinds of regular lattice fringe were observed in the core-shell structure. The lattice spacing in the core and in the shell were 0.208 and 0.335 nm, respectively, corresponding to the (021) plane of χ-Fe5C2 and (003) plane of graphite [36–38]. For the PB-C-530, PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts, there also had two kinds of regular lattice fringe in these catalysts. The lattice spacing in the core and in the shell were 0.202 and 0.335 nm, respectively, corresponding to the (110) plane of Fe and (003) plane of graphite. It is consistent with the XRD results in Fig. 3. The PB-C-530 catalyst displayed peaks of χ-Fe5C2. According to the HRTEM results, only the Fe lattice fringe can be seen in the catalyst but it cannot find the obvious lattice fringe of the χ-Fe5C2. One speculation is that a middle layer containing the mixture of crystal and amorphous of the χ-Fe5C2 between the carbon shell and Fe core. In addition, the same difference between HRTEM and XRD results of the PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts were also existed. These differences may also be explained by the formation of the obvious middle layers, like PB-C-530 catalyst (Fig. 6e-3, f-3). For these catalysts, with the calcination temperature increasing, the carbon shell of the catalysts became thinner (Fig. 6a-2, b-2, c-2, d-2, e-2 and f-2). The HRTEM results also suggested that the carbon loss in the PB is increasing with the calcination temperature increasing, and accompany by the formation of graphite carbon. In addition, the HRTEM results also indicated that the decarbonization of FeCx core in catalysts is from the inside to the outside. The textural property and Fe contents of the different catalysts were characterized and the results were listed in Table 2. As shown in Table 2, Fe was the most content in the catalysts, and its content increased with the calcination temperature increasing. In addition, the more carbon lost at the higher temperature, and this result was consistent with the TG, XRD and HRTEM results. In all catalysts, the Fe: Na weight ratio was nearly 100:9. The results of textural property analysis showed that the FeCx@C catalysts did not present high surface area, and the surface area of the catalysts presented a negative correlation with the calcination temperature except the PB-C-470 catalyst. That may be caused by the change of carbon morphology and structure. Compared to other Fe-based@C catalysts prepared from metal-organic materials, the FeCx@C catalysts calcined from PB presented much smaller surface areas [16]. In order to further investigate the surface property of the catalysts, XPS was carried out to characterize the surface composition and chemical state over the FeCx@C catalysts in Fig. 7. As shown in Fig. 7a, the C1s peaks of the catalysts at 283.6 eV, 284.6 eV, 285.4 eV, 286.4 eV and 289 eV were corresponded to carbide, graphite carbon, C-C, C-O and CO [39–41]. The carbon shells in all catalysts were detected in five different forms, with graphite carbon, carbides and disordered carbon were the major forms. These results were consistent with the Raman results. The Fe 2p spectra of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 7b. Three chemical states of Fe can be found in the catalysts: Fe0 (Binding energy (BE) 707.3 eV for Fe 2p3/2 and 721.0 eV for Fe 2p1/2), Fe3+ (BE 710.4 eV for Fe 2p3/2 and 724.1 eV for Fe 2p1/2), and iron carbide (BE 708.6 eV for Fe 2p3/2 and 722.1 eV for Fe 2p1/2) [42]. For the PB-C-450 and PB-C-470 catalysts (low temperature catalysts), there presented three iron chemical states in the catalysts: Fe0, Fe3+ and FeCx. However, two iron chemical states existed in the PB-C-500, PB-C-530, PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts (high temperature catalysts): Fe0 and Fe3+. For the high temperature catalysts, the peak of Fe0 2p1/2 was at 721.0 eV, but the peak of Fe0 2p1/2 transferred to 720.1 eV in the low temperature catalysts. This may due to the Fe0 was affected by the reduction environment in the low temperature catalysts. For the high temperature catalysts, the loss of FeCx may be attributed to gradual decarbonization and transformation of FeCx into metallic iron phase. These results also can be obtained from the XRD and HRTEM. It was reasonable to believe that the calcination temperature have a significance effect on the electronic state of Fe atoms, resulting in the formation of more Fe chemical states at the low temperature in FeCx catalysts. In many literatures, the iron carbides are very unstable and can be decomposed at higher temperature. Few works have investigated the FeCx existing forms by H2-TPR. However, the catalysts in this work were obtained from the thermal treatment, and the XRD results show that the iron carbide can exist at the high temperature. Therefore, in order to investigate the Fe existing form, the H2-TPR results are conducted to characterize the catalysts. The H2-TPR results of the different catalysts were shown in Fig. 8. As shown in the Fig. 8, all the catalysts presented reduction peaks at 250–280 °C, and PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalyst also had other peaks at the high temperature. For most of the catalysts (except PB-C-450 and PB-C-600), the reduction peaks of the catalyst gradually moved to the higher temperature as the calcination temperature increased. It suggested that the FeCx catalysts calcination at the higher thermal treatment temperature may be more stable, and the catalyst may be more difficult to be reduced [43,44]. For the PB-C-600 catalyst, the reduction peak shifted to the lower temperature. The smaller particles showed the reduction peak at the low temperature [44]. It may be caused by the smaller FeCx particles, and this may be another evidence for the PB-C-600 without FeCx peaks in XRD results. For the PB-C-450 catalyst, 4 reduction peaks were found at 240–400 °C, suggesting that the Fe were existed in many kinds of forms in this catalyst. For the catalysts obtained from high temperature (>500 °C), the area of the reduction peak was smaller than that of PB-C-500. With the increasing of temperature, the FeCx amount decreased, and the H2 consumption amount reduced. These results also can be obtained from the XRD, XPS and HRTEM. 3.3 FTS performances of the FeCx@C catalysts The syngas conversion was conducted over the FeCx@C catalysts at a fixed-bed reactor, and the results were shown in Table 3 and Fig. 9. As shown in Table 3, the CO conversions reached approximately 98% over the PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts. However, with the calcination temperature increasing, the CO conversion decreased to 41.9% over the PB-C-560 catalyst. The CO2 selectivities were above 30% over all catalysts, and even reached 50% over the PB-C-470 catalyst. For the FTS, there also exist oxygenates in the liquid products. The selectivity of oxygenates over PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts were about 5–7%. However, with the calcination temperature increasing, the selectivity of oxygenates was significantly reduced, and the oxygenated selectivity decreased to 1.4% over the PB-C-600 catalyst. The hydrocarbon distribution of FeCx@C catalysts was shown in Fig. 9. Methane selectivities were below 6% over all catalysts. Oils were the main products over all catalysts, and the oil selectivity even reached 75% over PB-C-500 catalyst. In addition, the values of carbon-chain growth probability (α values, and the ASF plots of hydrocarbons were presented in Fig. S1) of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 9. The α value presented the positive relationship with catalyst calcination temperature. In the FTS process, the FeCx active phase in catalysts determined the activity and products distribution. For the traditional methods, the FeCx active site was generated from iron, which was derived from hydrogenating iron oxides. The FeCx species were formed by added carbons and determined by the CO adsorption and dissociation states. In this manuscript, the FeCx active phases formed by removed carbon and presented a reverse process compared with the tradition methods. Moreover, the regular structure of PB also provided advantages for investigating the relationship between the FeCx structure and FTS activity. For PB-C-450, the main crystalline phase was Fe2C core, which had high carbon content and high activity in FTS. The α value of PB-C-450 was 0.71, and the product was mainly short chain without wax. For the PB-C-470 catalysts, the decarbonization degree of catalysts became deepened, and the FeCx core changed from ε-Fe2C to χ-Fe5C2. However, the PB-C-470 catalysts presented the similar activity and products distribution with the PB-C-450 catalyst. For the PB-C-500 catalyst, the FeCx core became mainly composed with χ-Fe5C2 and α-Fe. The PB-C-500 catalyst also presented the good activity for the CO conversion, and the α value was improved comparing with the PB-C-450 and PB-C-470 catalysts. For the activity of ε-Fe2C to χ-Fe5C2, researchers assumed some different suggestions. Datye et al. found that the χ-Fe5C2 presented high activity in activated catalyst and ε-Fe2C was the main phase in the deactivated catalysts [45]. However, Lyu et al. recently reported that the ε-Fe2C catalyst presented higher activity than χ-Fe5C2 [17]. Lu et al. also obtained the same results that the ε-Fe2C was more positive to activity than χ-Fe5C2 [46]. This manuscript provided evidence for the same results from the perspective of decarbonization. In this manuscript, the CO conversion reached 98% over the catalysts with ε-Fe2C and χ-Fe5C2 phases, and the catalysts with χ-Fe5C2 phase presented higher α value. For the PB-C-530 catalysts, the FeCx cores were composed by χ-Fe5C2, θ-Fe3C and α-Fe, and θ-Fe3C and α-Fe became the main compositions. Comparing with the catalysts prepared from low temperatures, the decarbonization degree of catalyst became further deepened. There PB-C-530 catalysts presented lower CO conversion and formed wax in the reaction. For the PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts, the Fe and θ-Fe3C became the main compositions in the FeCx cores. For the PB-C-600 catalyst, the wax selective can reach 38.6%, and the α value of catalyst became much bigger (0.82). The order of the catalyst’s activities followed as, PB-C-530 >PB-C-600 >PB-C-560. In many researches, θ-Fe3C was considered inactive and mainly appeared in deactivated catalyst. The χ-Fe5C2 improved the CO conversion in the PB-C-530, and the decrement of θ-Fe3C remove the barrier of CO conversion in the PB-C-600. These results were similar with the conclusion in the literatures [8,44–57]. Hensen et al. reported that the FeCx had higher intrinsic selectivity toward long chain hydrocarbons theoretically compared with cobalt at relatively low reaction temperature, and the lower selectivity toward long-chain hydrocarbons observed experimentally was actually a result of the high reaction temperature required for CO dissociation [47–53]. In the PB-C-530, PB-C-560, PB-C-600 catalysts, the wax were formed due to the high CO dissociative activity and high chain growth ability. Generally, some researchers reported that modified iron catalysts presented even higher wax selectivity than conventional cobalt catalysts, and these catalysts always comprised with some promoters and supports [13,47–48]. The comparison of FTS performance on the catalyst with the literatures was listed in Table S1. MES and TEM results were employed to quantitatively describe particle sizes and FeCx phases of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 6, all the catalyst particles showed the almost same sizes. However, the α value exhibited a positive relationship with the calcination temperature. The particle size of catalysts did not present the obvious connection with the α value. Compare to the particle size, the FeCx phases played more important role in the performance of these catalysts. Fig S2 presented correspondence between the FeCx contents and α value over the different catalysts. For the PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts, the α value presented the positive relationship with contents of χ-Fe5C2. For the PB-C-530, PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts, the content of α-Fe showed the positive relationship with the α value. χ-Fe5C2 and α-Fe also mentioned as active site for carbon chain growth in many literatures [58–60]. Therefore, the χ-Fe5C2 and the α-Fe may be the key factor for the catalyst, which influenced the α value, in the different decarburization stages. In order to gain a more comprehensive understanding of the catalysts, the spent catalysts were also characterized. Fig. S3 showed the XRD pattern of the spent catalysts. In Fig. S3, there no new peaks were created and no old peaks disappeared. As listed in Table S2, the spent catalysts presented the same FeCx phases as the fresh catalysts and the even the intensity of the peak did not show obvious differences. The TEM images of the spent catalyst were also showed in Fig. S4. It can be seen that the spent catalysts presented the similar particle size and carbon encapsulated core-shell structure as the fresh catalyst. It was reported that the carbon shell of the FeCx@C provided certain protective effect on the stability FeCx. Therefore, these catalysts performed the good structure stability. Fig. S5 also showed the durability test of PB-C-500 catalyst. The activity and the selectivity of the catalyst expressed good stability in144 hours. As FeCx@C core-shell catalysts the carbon shell also affected the FTS performance of the catalyst. In some literatures, carbon shell was considered as a factor to improve the catalyst stability in the Fe@C catalyst, owing to its function of inhibiting the particle aggregation and protecting the catalyst from oxidation [16,61]. However, in this work, the carbon shell of the catalysts, could keep the composition stable and gradually thinner with the prepared temperature increased, also showed a negative relationship with the α value. Generally, the thinner the carbon shell was, more easily long-carbon-chain products diffused. Therefore, it can be speculated that the FTS results of the catalyst may be due to the comprehensive effects of FeCx core and the carbon shell. 3.4 The CO adsorption behaviors and catalytic mechanism In order to investigate relationship between the CO adsorption behavior and the FTS performance on the FeCx@C catalysts, the CO-TPD was used to characterize the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 10, all the catalysts presented two CO desorption peaks at 240–270 °C and 390–410 °C respectively. For all the catalysts, with the calcination temperature increasing, the both desorption peaks of the catalyst gradually moved to the higher temperature. It suggested that the catalyst prepared from higher temperature presented the stronger CO adsorption ability. Generally, for the FTS reaction, the stronger CO adsorption ability always promoted heavier hydrocarbons formation in the products [62]. Therefore, this provided an explanation for the positive relationship between the α value and the calcination temperature. The area of desorption peak indicated the CO adsorption capacity on the catalysts. For all the FeCx@C catalysts, with the calcination temperature increasing, the area of CO desorption decreased, except the PB-C-600. The CO conversion exhibited the same rule with the CO adsorption capacity. For the PB-C-600, there presented a larger peak than PB-C-530 and PB-C-560 at ~400 °C. The more CO adsorption capacity suggested the higher CO conversion [63,64], which may be the reason for the higher CO conversion over the PB-C-600 catalyst. The in-situ DRIFTS was employed to study the mechanism of the CO conversion, and the results were shown in Fig. 11. For the in-situ DRIFTS spectrum, the region of 3100–2700 cm−1 was attributed to C-H stretching vibration [65]. The peak at 3014 cm−1 was assigned to the CH bond stretching vibration of free CH4, and the peak at 2875 cm−1 was the CH bond stretching vibration of -CH3 [66]. Hydrocarbons were the main products in the FTS reaction. The high intensity of peaks at PB-C-450, PB-C-470, PB-C-500 catalysts suggested that these catalysts presented high activity for syngas to hydrocarbons. The peak at 2090 cm−1 was assigned to the linear adsorption of CO, and the peak at 1972 cm–1 was assigned to bridge adsorption of CO. The peaks at 1972 cm−1 were obviously observed at PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts, which indicated that CO was mainly bridged adsorption in these three catalysts. While, the peaks at 2090 cm−1 were mainly observed at PB-C-530，PB-C-560 and PB-C-600 catalysts. With the calcination temperature increasing, the type of CO adsorption changed from bridged adsorption gradually to linear adsorption [67,68]. Moreover, the CC bond stretching vibration of -CC- at 1640 cm−1 [69], were obviously observed at PB-C-450, PB-C-470 and PB-C-500 catalysts. The high intensity of peaks at PB-C-450, PB-C-470, PB-C-500 catalysts also indicated that these catalysts presented high activity for syngas to hydrocarbons. The same results can also be obtained from the FTS evaluation. Generally, the CO linear adsorption needed higher binding energy than bridge adsorption over Fe-based catalysts [70,71]. In the CO-TPD results, with the calcination temperature increasing, the desorption peaks on the catalyst gradually shifted to the higher temperature. It speculated that the CO linear adsorption become the more types in the catalysts prepared from higher calcination temperature. The α value presented consistent variation rule with the CO linear adsorption on the catalysts. Based on the above discussion, the CO-TPD results showed that the CO adsorption ability and capacity of the catalyst played the key role in the CO conversion and product distribution. In addition, the in-situ DRIFTS results showed that phase of FeCx affected the type of the CO adsorption, and then influenced CO adsorption ability and capacity of the catalyst. In summary, the change of FeCx phase in the FeCx@C catalyst, varied the type of the CO adsorption, and then affected the activity and selectivity of catalyst. Specifically, the CO bridged adsorption led to the high catalytic activity and low chain growth ability. Otherwise, the CO linear adsorption led to the opposite results. In this manuscript, the activity and products distribution were closely associated with the structure of FeCx@C in the catalysts. With the calcination temperature increasing, the deep of decarbonization increased, and the CO conversion decreased firstly and then increased, and the α value increased. However, the activity and selectivity over the different FeCx species had been long debated. This manuscript provided evidences for the relationship between FeCx species and catalytic performance in FTS from the perspective of decarbonization. 4 Conclusions This work explored controlled preparation of FeCx@C catalysts with continuously adjustment structures and their application in FTS reaction. The FeCx@C catalysts can be successfully prepared by PB thermal treated above 450 °C. Moreover, with the calcination temperature increasing, the carbon loss was observed as expected. The FeCx were encapsulated in amorphous carbon matrix directly, and the phases of FeCx core and the thicknesses of carbon shell in the FeCx@C catalysts can be continuously adjusted. With the preparation temperature increasing, the FeCx structures in the catalysts presented the evolutional rule as: ε-Fe2C→χ-Fe5C2→θ-Fe3C →α-Fe. Moreover, with the calcination temperature increasing, the CO conversion decreased firstly and then increased, and α value increased. Finally, the CO-TPD and in-situ DRIFTS results showed that the variety of CO adsorption type may be the reason for the catalyst activity change. This manuscript did not only provide a simple and cheap way to prepare effective FTS catalyst, but also present a new perspective to investigate the relationship between the activity and FeCx species in the catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The activity and selectivity of the Fe-based catalysts with different FeCx species had been long debated in Fischer-Tropsch Synthesis (FTS). In this manuscript, FeCx was encapsulated in carbon matrix by Prussian blue (Fe4(Fe(CN)6)3, PB) thermal treated, and the FeCx@C catalysts could be directly prepared. With the calcination temperature increasing, the FeCx species of core and the thickness of carbon shell in FeCx@C catalysts can be continuously tuned through adjusting the calcination temperature. Further characterization results suggested that the decarburization of FeCx@C catalyst occurred from the inside to the outside. In addition, the FTS results showed the value of carbon-chain growth probability (α value) presented the positive relationship with the catalyst calcination temperature. This work provides a novel and simple route to synthesize FeCx@C catalyst, and also provides evidence for the mechanism of FeCx species from the perspective of decarburization.
coredata.dc:title: FeCx@C catalysts prepared from Prussian blue and their applications in Fischer-Tropsch synthesis
